title: Gov. DeWine announces 2024-2026 Suicide Prevention Plan
text:
This story mentions suicide. If you or someone you know is struggling with suicidal thoughts, you can call or text 988. For more resources, click here.
OHIO — Gov. Mike DeWine has announced the state’s 2024-2026 Suicide Prevention Plan, according to a press release from his office.
What You Need To Know Gov. Mike DeWine has announced the state’s 2024-2026 Suicide Prevention Plan
The plan is a partnership between DeWine’s RecoveryOhio initiative and the Ohio Suicide Prevention Foundation
The plan, which received input from 30 different organizations, will focus on raising awareness, improving data, expand access to health care and provide support to those who have lost someone to suicide
If you or someone you know is struggling with thoughts of suicide, you can call or text 988 The plan, the release states, is a partnership between DeWine’s RecoveryOhio initiative and the Ohio Suicide Prevention Foundation that seeks to “promote life-saving strategies statewide.”
“The heartbreak of losing a family member to suicide is a pain that cuts deep, leaving behind a void that words can't fully capture,“ DeWine said in the release. “This plan will bring about a system-wide commitment to reduce suicides and encourage communities to work collectively to foster understanding and destigmatize mental health challenges.”
The plan, which received input from 30 different organizations, will focus on raising awareness, improving data, expand access to health care and provide support to those who have lost someone to suicide, according to the release.
“It underscores the importance of collaborative efforts with behavioral health care providers, employers, health care systems, schools, and community organizations to stem the increasing rates of suicides,” the release states.
The release cites data from the Ohio Department of Health , saying Ohio saw 1,766 suicides in 2021, an 8% increase from 2020. The year 2018 saw the highest in a decade with 1,836.
The release also cited national data from the Centers for Disease Control , reporting nearly 50,000 deaths by suicide in 2022, with middle-aged adults being the highest cohort.
“We are grateful for Governor DeWine’s leadership and focus on improving the lives of individuals who are struggling with mental health and suicide,” said Tony Coder, executive director of the Ohio Suicide Prevention Foundation, in the release. “We believe that suicide prevention is a health issue that anyone can be an active participant in and we are grateful that this plan is a strategy that can help more individuals seek care.”
